prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for taking my 3yo out to do something fun whilst my partner is at work?
I will try and keep this short . 

Almost every weekend when I say lets take our kid out to the play centre or a farm ect I get one of maybe 3  excuses every time without fail . Either "I dont want to go out / I just wanna sit and play on the computer. " " ive been at work im tired I don't wanna go out / drive " or " I don't wanna spend the money on x, y ,z" ( we have money so its not like thats a real problem )   

Today a friend asked me if i wanted to go with her with the kids to the farm near us tomorrow and I said yes . I figured since we hadn't taken little one anywhere fun for a few weeks it would be nice . 

So I mentioned it to my partner and he goes off on one about how its not fair as he is at work and he would like to go blah blah . I said so I cant take her anywhere when you're at work ? Pointed out that I asked to go not a week or two earlier and was told no its too expencive and  I dont want to go out I'm tired. ( its £7 each ). 

So now he wants me to cancle with my friend so he can go another day . I said we can go whenever you want . But apparently thats not an option either . 

Its a childrens petting zoo ffs its not like im going to see a movie wothout him. 
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the person who wrote the AITA (Am I the Asshole) post is in the wrong. The situation is about taking a 3-year-old child to a fun activity while the partner is at work.

First, I need to understand the key points. The author mentions that every weekend when they want to take the kid out to places like a play center or a farm, the partner gives excuses such as not wanting to go, being tired, not wanting to spend money (even though they can afford it). The author decided to go with a friend to a farm because they hadn't done anything fun in a while. When they told the partner, he got upset because he was at work and wanted to go himself. The author pointed out that previous requests were denied, and the cost is only £7 each. The partner now wants them to cancel so he can go another day, but the author says they can go whenever the partner wants, which isn't an option for him.

The user thinks the author is in the wrong but is curious about others' opinions. They want a simple answer: A (Yes, author is wrong) or B (No, author is not wrong).

So, to evaluate, I need to consider if the author's actions are justifiable. The main issues here are partnership dynamics, communication, and shared responsibilities.

The author is taking initiative to spend quality time with the child, which is a positive thing. The partner has been consistently making excuses, which might indicate a lack of willingness to engage in family activities. The author's decision to go with a friend could be seen as a necessary step to provide the child with enriching experiences, especially if the partner is uncooperative. However, the author did inform the partner beforehand, which is good communication. The partner's reaction seems to stem from feeling excluded or not involved, but if he has been dismissive of previous plans, the author might be justified in seeking alternatives.

On the flip side, the partner might feel that the author didn't consult him first or that the author is making unilateral decisions. But in this case, the author mentioned the plans to the partner and only went after being told no in the past. The cost is minimal, so money isn't a real issue. The activity is child-friendly, so it's not a date or something that excludes the partner. The author's response that they can go whenever the partner wants shows willingness to accommodate, but the partner's work schedule might not allow it. 

In terms of fairness, the author is trying to provide for the child's needs when the partner isn't fulfilling that role. The partner's excuses might be signs of disengagement or resentment. The author isn't doing anything harmful; they're ensuring the child has fun and social activities. Therefore, the author isn't in the wrong here. The partner might need to reflect on his own behavior and willingness to participate in family life.
